name: Monitoring & Observability
description: Monitoring and observability are essential DevOps practices that help you understand the health, performance, and reliability of your applications and infrastructure. In this topic, you'll learn how to set up monitoring using Prometheus and visualize metrics with Grafana. You'll then explore AI agents with n8n to automate incident response.

learning_steps.description:
Cloud-native applications need monitoring because they:

• Help detect and resolve issues quickly, minimizing downtime
• Provide visibility into system health and performance
• Enable proactive alerting and troubleshooting
• Support scalability by identifying bottlenecks
• Help understand dependencies between microservices

learning_steps.title: Monitoring vs Observability
learning_steps.description: Understand the difference between monitoring and observability in DevOps.

• Metrics - Quantitative data about your systems (CPU, memory, requests)
• Alerting - Automated notifications based on metric thresholds
• Dashboards - Visual representations of metrics for quick insights
• Instrumentation - Adding code or exporters to expose metrics

learning_steps.code:
# Create prometheus.yml config:
global:
  scrape_interval: 15s

scrape_configs:
  - job_name: 'prometheus'
    static_configs:
      - targets: ['localhost:9090']

# Run Prometheus container:
docker run \
  -p 9090:9090 \
  -v /path/to/prometheus.yml:/etc/prometheus/prometheus.yml \
  prom/prometheus

learning_steps.description: Install Grafana and connect to Prometheus:
learning_steps.code:
# Run Grafana container:
docker run -d --name=grafana -p 3000:3000 grafana/grafana

# Access Grafana at http://localhost:3000
# Default login: admin / admin

# Add Prometheus as data source:
# URL: http://host.docker.internal:9090

learning_steps.description:
AI agents can enhance monitoring by:

• Responding instantly to alerts without human delays
• Analyzing logs and metrics to find root causes automatically
• Executing fixes (restart services, scale resources) independently
• Learning from incidents to improve future responses
• Freeing teams from repetitive troubleshooting
Understand AI agents and agentic workflows:

learning_steps.text: Build an AI Agent with n8n
learning_steps.action: Hands-on: Build an AI Agent with n8n
learning_steps.description:
1. Install n8n: `docker run -d -p 5678:5678 --name n8n n8nio/n8n:latest`
2. Access n8n at http://localhost:5678
3. Build your agent workflow:
   • Create a Schedule trigger (every 1-2 minutes)
   • Query Prometheus API for a specific metric
   • Add an If node to check threshold
   • Call an LLM to analyze anomalies and suggest remediation
   • Send analysis via email or Slack
   • (Optional) Add automated remediation steps
4. Test by intentionally triggering high traffic or errors
